p: The crucial hint on how to improve became evident when removing the constraint of equal ADPs between Si p and B p atoms (model 2). The resulting R 1 and Δρ values were again reduced significantly and the composition swung back to SiB 2.58(1). The split B p–Si p distance decreased to 0.28 Å and the ADP of the B p atom almost doubled ( U eq = 0.019 Å 2) and became strongly prolate, with the long axis pointing toward the Si p atom. The largest negative Q-peak of −1.14 e/Å 3 is now located inside the icosahedron close to the B p atom. This B p position is now conveniently split into two individual boron positions B p,Si and B p,B (model 3) after which the negative Q-peak disappeared, along with a further reduced R 1. (The notation B p, A has been chosen to indicate that the boron atom shows a reasonable exo-distance with respect to an atom A in the neighboring icosahedron.) Note that the ADP for these split boron atoms was kept equal for stability reasons and the sum of the occupancies for B p,Si, B p,B, and Si p was constrained to unity.
